title: R43858
content: The funding authorization for the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) expires on September 30, 2015, and the report discusses topics likely to arise during reauthorization debates in the 114th Congress. Most FAA programs are financed through the Airport and Airway Trust Fund (AATF). The Airport and Airway Trust Fund (AATF) was established in 1970 to expand the nation's airports and air traffic system. It provides 66.6% to 71.4% of FAA's annual funding through various revenue sources like passenger ticket taxes, air cargo fees, and fuel taxes. In 2013, the AATF had revenues of almost $12.9 billion with a cash balance of over $13 billion, but the uncommitted balance has decreased since 2001. The Airport and Airway Trust Fund (AATF) had a cash balance of over $13 billion in 2013, but the uncommitted balance dropped to $299 million in 2009 due to the global economic crisis. By the end of FY2014, the balance rebounded to $1.3 billion. The trust fund balance is projected to grow in the near term as revenue rises and airport capital needs decline. However, long-term concerns exist due to reductions in general fund appropriations to FAA and changes in airline business practices affecting AATF revenue. Airlines impose fees for various options and amenities, excluding them from the base ticket price to avoid federal excise taxes. The U.S. Government Accountability Office estimated potential revenue of $186 million in FY2009 from untaxed baggage fees. Airlines argue that general aviation operators, especially corporate jets, should contribute more to the trust fund, but general aviation interests disagree, stating that nonairline users already pay a fair share. Proposals to increase general aviation jet fuel tax in 2012 were not approved. The Clinton, George W. Bush, and Obama Administrations proposed per-flight user charges, with President Obama suggesting a $100-per-flight charge on commercial and general aviation jets since 2011. The Senate considered a $25-per-flight fee in the 110th Congress, but none of these proposals became law. FAA funding, totaling between $15 billion and $16 billion annually, is divided among four main accounts, with Operations and Maintenance (O&M) receiving the largest portion for air traffic operations and aviation safety programs. The O&M account funds air traffic operations and aviation safety programs. The Airport Improvement Program (AIP) provides federal grants for airport projects. The Facilities and Equipment (F&E) account funds air traffic facilities and equipment. The Research, Engineering, and Development account finances research on aviation safety and efficiency. The federal government supports airport infrastructure development through the AIP. The Airport Improvement Program (AIP) provides federal grants for airport projects, including capital projects for aircraft operations. Airports can also assess a Passenger Facility Charge (PFC) on boarding passengers for various projects. Investors receive tax benefits on bonds issued for airport improvements. Airports can also use state and local funds, operating revenues, and different funding sources for specific projects. The funding sources for airport projects include state and local grants, airport revenues, tax-exempt bonds, and Passenger Facility Charges (PFCs). Different airports rely on various funding sources, with larger airports more likely to use bonds and PFCs. These funding sources come with legislative, regulatory, and contractual constraints. A 2007 study showed that bonds financed 50% of airport capital spending, AIP 29%, PFCs 17%, state and local contributions 4%, and airport revenue 4%. Assessing airport capital needs is crucial for determining federal support to maintain a safe and efficient national airport system. The U.S. passenger airline industry has undergone bankruptcies and mergers since 2000, leading to a reduction in commercial flights. Carriers have consolidated operations, resulting in a 15-18% decrease in flights since 2005. Airlines have shown capacity discipline by flying fuller planes, with an average load factor of over 83% in 2014. The reduced number of flights may alleviate pressure on airport and air traffic control facilities, but on-time performance has not significantly improved. The U.S. passenger airline industry has seen bankruptcies and mergers, leading to fewer flights. Despite consolidation, on-time performance has not improved, indicating ongoing capacity issues. FAA and ACI-NA have differing estimates for airports' long-term financial needs, with FAA projecting $42.5 billion and ACI-NA estimating $71.3 billion for FY2013-FY2017. The disparity in estimates is due to differing views on which airport projects to include. FAA's estimate is based on airport master plans and state system plans, screening out projects not justified by aviation forecasts or eligible for AIP grants. The FAA study includes only designated airports and projects justified by aviation forecasts or eligible for AIP grants. In contrast, the ACI-NA study includes a wider range of projects funded by PFCs, bonds, state or local funding, airport-funded air traffic control facilities, security projects, and AIP-ineligible projects. This leads to a higher estimate of capital needs by ACI-NA compared to FAA. The FAA focuses on evaluating capital needs at the largest airports, which handle the majority of commercial passenger boardings. The FAA has conducted studies to determine critical improvements at major airports to increase system capacity. The most recent study, FACT3, found that the air traffic system is more reliable with reduced congestion due to structural changes in the airline industry and runway expansions. While NextGen helps manage delays, new capacity solutions are still needed to address traffic growth and reduce delays at busy airports. The study projects interim and long-term airport capacity needs up to 2030. The FAA conducted studies to identify critical improvements at major airports for increased system capacity. The latest study, FACT3, showed that while capacity constraints have improved, several busy airports, including those in New York City, Philadelphia, and Atlanta, will remain constrained. The Airport Improvement Program (AIP) provides federal grants for airport development, focusing on aircraft operation improvements like runways and taxiways. Commercial revenue facilities and operating costs are not eligible for AIP funding, reflecting congressional priorities for airport safety. The Airport Improvement Program (AIP) provides federal grants for airport development, focusing on safety, security, capacity, congestion reduction, noise mitigation, and financing for small airports. AIP grants do not require airports to take on debt financing, but a local match is needed. Limitations include project eligibility and adherence to regulations. The Secretary of Transportation publishes a biannual National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems (NPIAS) to guide airport development. The AIP program requires airports to be listed in the National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems (NPIAS) to receive funds. Grant funding for AIP has fluctuated over the years, with gaps between authorized spending levels and actual expenditures. The AIR-21 Act in 2000 increased AIP's authorization levels significantly. The AIP program, authorized by P.L. 106-181 in 2000, saw major funding increases starting in FY2001. Funding peaked at $3.47 billion in FY2008, with annual obligation limitations set at $3.515 billion from FY2008 to FY2011. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 authorized funding at $3.35 billion annually through FY2015. AIP grants are distributed through formula grants and discretionary funds, with entitlements apportioned first to specific airports before the remaining funds are allocated as discretionary funds for airport projects. The AIP program provides formula grants and discretionary funds for airport projects. Entitlements are apportioned by formula to airports and can be used for various improvement projects. Funds are divided into categories based on airport type, with different distribution formulas. Airports have up to three years to use their apportionments, with a higher limit for nonhub commercial service airports. Formula distributions depend on an annual AIP obligation limitation of $3.2 billion or more. The AIP program provides formula grants and discretionary funds for airport projects, with entitlements apportioned based on airport type and usage. For primary airports with over 10,000 passengers annually, funding is determined by passenger boardings in the prior year. The allocation ranges from $7.80 to $0.50 per boarding, with a minimum of $1 million and a maximum of $26 million. Additionally, 3.5% of AIP funds are allocated to cargo service airports. AIP funds are apportioned to airports based on various criteria, including passenger boardings and landed weight for cargo service airports. General aviation airports receive 20% of AIP funds, with the remaining funds distributed based on state population and area. FAA decides on project allocations in consultation with states. Alaska Supplemental Funds ensure Alaskan airports receive double the funding they did in 1980. Large and medium hub airports with low passenger facility charges have their AIP entitlements reduced until they give back a portion of their grants. Small airports receive discretionary grants from the forgone funds. The discretionary fund, comprising 12.5% of total AIP funding, includes money not distributed under apportioned entitlements and forgone PFC revenues. FAA approves discretionary grants based on project priority and selection criteria. Allocations are subject to set-asides for noise compatibility planning, military airport program, and other spending criteria. The discretionary fund, comprising 12.5% of total AIP funding, includes money not distributed under apportioned entitlements and forgone PFC revenues. FAA approves discretionary grants based on project priority and selection criteria. Allocations are subject to set-asides for noise compatibility planning, military airport program, and other spending criteria. Additionally, there is a set-aside for conversion and dual use of up to 15 current and former military airports, as well as grants for reliever airports in metropolitan areas suffering from flight delays. The Secretary of Transportation ensures that 75% of grants enhance capacity, safety, and security at primary and reliever airports, with $5 million set aside for testing innovative aviation security systems. The remaining 25% of grants are at the discretion of the Secretary of Transportation through FAA. The FAA provides funds directly to participating states for projects at airports classified as other than primary airports through a block grant program. Participating states are responsible for selecting and funding AIP projects at small airports, complying with federal priorities. States in the state block grant program include Georgia, Illinois, Michigan, Missouri, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Texas, and Wisconsin. The federal government's share for AIP projects varies depending on the type of airport. The federal government's share for AIP projects at airports varies based on airport type. Large and medium hub airports receive 75% federal share (80% for noise projects), other airports receive 90%, states in the block grant program receive "not more than" 90%, airports with exemptions under 49 U.S.C. Section 47134 receive 70%, economically distressed communities may get up to 95% federal share. Smaller airports pay a lower share of project costs compared to larger airports. Smaller airports receive a higher percentage of AIP-funded project costs compared to larger airports, with the remaining share needing to be raised from other sources. Noncommercial airports are particularly reliant on AIP grants, receiving over 30% of grants in FY2012. Grant applications require assurances for future airport operations, such as public availability and fair economic practices. Assurances within the AIP context guarantee federal policy implementation for airports, extending obligations beyond project closure for up to 20 years. Airports can request release from AIP obligations by reimbursing grants or reinvesting in approved projects. Decisions on airport expansion projects, particularly runway projects at large and medium hub airports, have implications for the reauthorization of the Airport Improvement Program (AIP) in 2015. These projects can have long lead times and may require AIP funding in earlier years. If airports levy passenger facility charges, they may need to rely on AIP discretionary funds for runway projects. Constraints on the AIP budget in the future could impact funding for these projects. If the entitlement formulas remain unchanged during the appropriations process, the discretionary portion of the AIP budget may be limited, affecting large airports' capacity expansion projects. Congress could prioritize capacity enhancement at large and medium hub airports by adjusting AIP funds distribution, such as eliminating the requirement for airports imposing maximum PFCs to forgo part of their entitlement. This could deplete small airport funds but increase grants for larger airports. Alternatively, changes in discretionary fund set-asides could give FAA more flexibility for capacity enhancement, potentially reducing funding for noise mitigation and other purposes. Changes in FAA authorization acts have increased entitlements and expanded landside projects eligible for AIP grants, benefiting smaller airports. The increased apportioned funds have limited discretionary grants for major airports' operational evolution plan projects. Allowing large and medium hub airports to opt out of AIP and rely on PFCs for financing could reduce trust fund revenue needed for AIP. This could conflict with the goal of reducing congestion at major commercial airports. Some airports may choose to rely solely on Passenger Facility Charges (PFCs) instead of Airport Improvement Program (AIP) funding. This would require raising the federal cap on PFCs and could lead to airports being released from certain AIP grant assurances. The PFC was introduced in 1990 as a user charge to supplement AIP funding. Initially capped at $3 per passenger, the PFC allows airports to impose a fee on each boarding passenger. The Passenger Facility Charge (PFC) is a fee imposed by airports on boarding passengers, initially capped at $3 per passenger. The PFC funds must be used for eligible airport-related projects and can also be used to service debt. In 2000, the PFC ceiling was raised to $4.50 with an $18 limit per round trip. Airports must show that funded projects will improve air safety, increase competition, or reduce congestion or noise impacts to impose a PFC above $3. The Passenger Facility Charge (PFC) can be raised above $3 to fund projects improving air safety, competition, or reducing congestion. Large and medium hub airports forgo 75% of AIP formula funds when imposing PFCs above $3. Approval for PFCs at these airports requires a competition plan submission to the FAA. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 made changes to the PFC program, including allowing nonhub small airports to impose PFCs and requiring GAO to study alternative collection methods. The Passenger Facility Charge (PFC) revenues are used for landside projects like terminals and transit systems, as well as interest payments. PFC collections grew significantly from $85.4 million in 1992 to $2.9 billion in 2014. Air carriers are less involved in PFC project planning compared to AIP grants. The central legislative issue related to PFCs is whether to raise the $4.50 per enplaned passenger ceiling or eliminate it altogether. Airports advocate for increasing or eliminating the ceiling, while air carriers and some passenger advocates oppose higher limits on PFCs. A GAO study in January 2015 showed that raising the cap would significantly increase PFC collections available to airports, but could also marginally slow passenger growth. The GAO report suggests that higher PFCs could marginally slow passenger growth and revenue to the Airport and Airway Trust Fund. Airport operators want more freedom to use PFC funds for off-airport projects, while carriers complain about airports using funds for low-priority projects. Major carriers are also unhappy with their limited influence over project decisions. The Airport Privatization Pilot Program (APPP) was established in 1996 to explore privatizing publicly owned airports in the United States. While privatization has been promoted as a way to improve efficiency and financial viability, participation in the program has been limited. Only two airports have completed privatization, with one later reverting to public ownership. The lack of interest in privatization among U.S. airports may be due to readily available financing for publicly owned airports and barriers to privatization. Airport privatization in the United States has been limited, with most cases falling under partial privatization. This involves outsourcing noncore operations to private firms, such as cleaning services and shuttle operations. Full privatization, either under or outside the Airport Privatization Pilot Program (APPP), is rare. Outsourcing of cleaning, landscaping, shuttle operations, and concessions is common in U.S. airports. Management contracts involve private sector expertise for parking, terminal operations, and more. Developer financing and operation models, like DBFOM, are used for airport projects. Examples include Terminal 5 at Chicago O'Hare International Airport. Passenger terminals, parking garages, and rental car facilities at airports can be privatized through long-term lease or sale to a private owner or operator. This involves transferring management and development control in exchange for capital improvements and other obligations. While several airports in Europe have been privatized this way, there have been no sales of commercial service airports in the United States. Airport privatization involves airport owners, private operators, and other stakeholders. Airport privatization involves four major stakeholders: airport owners (mostly local or regional governments), air carriers, private investors, and the federal government. These stakeholders have different objectives and interests. Passenger interests are not formally represented in discussions of privatization. Airport owners may see privatization as a revenue source, but federal regulations dictate that revenue must be used for airport purposes unless the majority of airlines agree otherwise. Privatization of airports involves surrendering control of a facility, potentially leading to loss of public-sector jobs. Public-sector owners may not benefit unless the airport is losing money. The APPP grants exemptions to encourage privatization, but airlines want to keep costs low and have control over revenue usage. Air carriers have an interest in well-maintained airports and may support privatization for lower charges and better services. Private investors seek financial returns through growth opportunities like additional flights, improved amenities, and increased freight traffic. The FAA is directed to engage private capital in aviation infrastructure development and reduce reliance on federal grants. They also have mandates to maintain safety and enforce compliance with grant assurances. Privatization proposals that may reduce aviation system capacity or favor certain users will be carefully examined. Stakeholders' divergent interests are a significant issue in privatization. The APPP aims to balance interests in privatization by exempting airports from certain requirements. Participation was initially limited to five airports but was increased to ten in 2012. Only one large hub commercial airport can participate by leasing, not selling, while general aviation airports can be sold under the program. The Airport Privatization Pilot Program (APPP) allows for the sale of general aviation airports. Since its inception, 10 airports have applied to enter the program, with two completing privatization. Stewart International Airport in Newburgh, NY, was the first commercial service airport privatized under the APPP in 2000 by National Express Group PLC. National Express Group privatized Stewart International Airport in 2000 under the Airport Privatization Pilot Program. Despite making a $10 million capital contribution, the company struggled to increase passenger traffic. Attempts to rename the airport and attract more passengers to New York City were met with local opposition. In 2006, National Express shifted its focus to school bus operations in the U.S. In 2006, National Express decided to focus on school bus operations in the U.S. and sold its lease on Stewart International Airport to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for $78.5 million. The Port Authority reported losses of $0.8 million in 2007 and $5.5 million in 2008 while operating the airport, indicating it may not have been profitable for the private owner. National Express, however, made a profit of £16.2 million on the sale, suggesting a significant return on investment. Juan, Puerto Rico, is the only commercial service airport operating under private management after privatization under the APPP. Aerostar Airport Holdings paid $615 million upfront to the Puerto Rico Ports Authority and agreed to a $1.2 billion capital plan, including a $200 million terminal reconfiguration. The only airport currently seeking privatization approval under the APPP is Hendry County Airglades Airport in Clewiston, FL, which received preliminary approval from the FAA in October 2010. Airglades International Airport LLC, controlled by owners of adjacent sugar plantations, plans to build an additional runway and a perishable air cargo complex near the airport. The APPP slot reserved for a large hub commercial airport was once held by Chicago Midway Airport, which was leased to private investors in a $2.52 billion, 99-year deal with MIDCo consortium. The lease agreement for Chicago Midway Airport was terminated in 2009 due to financing issues during the global economic crisis. MIDCo had to pay a $126 million penalty to the city. A renewed effort to lease Midway was abandoned in 2013, leading to the city suspending plans for privatization. The City of Chicago withdrew its privatization application in 2013, opening up the APPP slot for a large hub airport. The APPP program has not been successful in generating widespread interest in airport privatization due to time-consuming processes. The FAA process for transferring airports from public to private ownership is time-consuming and risky, taking years to complete. The application process involves submitting a preliminary application with privatization objectives, financial statements, and a request for private operators to submit proposals. FAA has 30 days to review the application. The FAA process for transferring airports to private ownership involves submitting a preliminary application with privatization objectives and financial statements. Once an airport receives preliminary approval, it may select a private operator, negotiate an agreement, and submit a final application to FAA. After FAA gives notice of its proposed approval in the Federal Register, there is a 60-day public review period. Airport privatization under the APPP has regulatory requirements that may lessen interest in privatization. Airport privatization under the Airport Privatization Pilot Program (APPP) has regulatory requirements that may reduce interest in privatization. These requirements include the need for approval from 65% of air carriers, restrictions on rate increases exceeding the CPI, and compliance with previous grant assurances. Additionally, privatized airports are eligible for only 70% of AIP grants for improvements, serving as a disincentive due to receiving less federal funding post-privatization. In surface transportation, privatization aims to attract private capital to supplement insufficient public spending for construction and maintenance. Publicly owned airports have access to five major sources of funding, including federal grants from the AIP for planning and development, passenger facility charges, tax-exempt bonds, tenant leases, landing fees, and state and local grants. These funding sources support capital projects related to aircraft operations and other improvements on airport property. The financing arrangements for airport privatization have implications on funding sources. Privatized airports outside the APPP may not receive AIP formula funds and would have to rely on their own resources for improvements. Private operators would not have access to federal tax-exempt bonds, leading to higher interest rates. However, they would have more flexibility in imposing fees and charges. Privatized airports under APPP would still have access to federal grants but with a higher matching requirement. The operator of a privatized airport in the United States would need to provide a 30% match for funding, pay higher interest rates on bonds, and face limitations on fees and charges due to federal laws. This contrasts with Europe and Canada where airport privatization has been more successful, partly because major airports there were previously owned by national governments. In Europe and Canada, airports privatized were previously owned by national governments, simplifying the decision-making process. Unlike the US, the tax benefits for debt issued by state and local governments are not common in other countries, reducing borrowing costs in privatization. Congress aims to save money and increase aviation capacity through airport privatization, but current federal laws hinder these goals. Privatization outside the APPP framework is unappealing due to higher financing costs and potential investor disinterest. Privatization under the APPP framework may not benefit public-sector owners or air carriers, except in cases of financial loss or capital project needs. Private investors face limitations on earning money from privatized airports due to restrictions on fees. Streamlining the APPP process could make privatization more attractive by reducing risks. Privatization may become more appealing by streamlining the process and reducing risks. Structural changes to airport financing, such as equal tax treatment for private and public airport bonds, could further increase interest in airport privatization. Privatization of airports could be made more attractive by changing AIP requirements, relaxing grant assurances, and liberalizing rules governing fees. These changes may increase private investor interest but could impact federal revenues and aviation system capacity and safety. Privatization of airports could be more appealing to investors by increasing facility charges and raising rents and landing fees. However, this may face opposition from airlines and lead to higher costs for passengers and air cargo shippers. Easing limits on the use of privatization revenue could stimulate government interest in privatization but may result in lower investment in aviation infrastructure. Noise from aircraft is a concern at many airports, with regulations in place to assess environmental impacts, including noise, associated with airport projects and airspace redesigns. Noise has been a contentious issue in airspace redesign in the New York City, New Jersey, and Philadelphia region. The redesign of airspace in the New York City, New Jersey, and Philadelphia region has raised noise concerns, as seen in airport expansion projects like the new runway at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport in 2013. The number of residents in the US exposed to significant aircraft noise has decreased significantly over the years, with major reductions achieved through phasing out louder Stage 2 airliners and implementing quieter noise standards for jet airplanes. The FAA is also planning to introduce even more stringent Stage 5 noise standards. The FAA, in collaboration with NASA and industry, has invested in research for quieter aircraft technologies, resulting in significant noise reductions. Despite advancements, air traffic volume has increased around major airports. Congress historically allocates 35% of AIP funding for noise mitigation within DNL 65 dB areas. Proposals suggest granting FAA flexibility to fund projects in lower DNL areas. The FAA is considering granting flexibility to fund noise mitigation projects in areas with lower DNL levels, which could support additional abatement projects but may divert resources from capacity and safety projects. NextGen is a modernization initiative to improve air traffic technologies and procedures for increased capacity, with full-scale implementation targeted by 2025. NextGen aims to enhance air traffic management by reducing separation, improving spacing and sequencing of aircraft, utilizing airspace and airports more efficiently, providing tailored weather forecasts, and reducing environmental impacts. The Vision 100 Act established the JPDO to develop and implement NextGen to meet projected air traffic demands by 2025. The JPDO released the Integration National Plan for NextGen in 2004, aiming to transform the national airspace system by 2025 to meet safety, security, mobility, efficiency, and capacity needs. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 refined NextGen implementation, establishing the Chief NextGen Officer position and requiring strategic objectives for NextGen planning and development. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 mandated the acceleration of NextGen technologies deployment at airports, with specific performance metrics to be tracked by the FAA. It also required reviews of ADS-B ground system installation and enterprise architecture for NextGen. Additionally, the act authorized the evaluation of airport surveillance technologies for NextGen airport surface operations management. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 mandated the acceleration of NextGen technologies deployment at airports, with specific performance metrics to be tracked by the FAA. It also required reviews of ADS-B ground system installation and enterprise architecture for NextGen. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2014 defunded the JPDO for FY2014 and directed FAA to absorb the JPDO's functions into its operations account under the NextGen and operations planning activity. In May 2014, FAA moved the JPDO functions into a newly created NextGen Interagency Planning Office. The NextGen concept integrates air traffic control infrastructure with aircraft navigation and communication devices, originating from cargo airlines' efforts to develop low-cost collision avoidance and tracking technologies using GPS. Global Positioning System (GPS) technology, developed by UPS Aviation Technologies in the 1990s, played a key role in the development of ADS-B technology, now a core component of the NextGen system. UPS Aviation Technologies was later acquired by Garmin Ltd., a major supplier of GPS navigation devices and advanced avionics for small to midsized general aviation aircraft. Additionally, in 1999, FAA initiated the Capstone Program in Alaska to explore the safety benefits of GPS, ADS-B, and advanced avionics for general aviation operations. The FAA created an Operational Evolution Plan (OEP) in 2001 to address future capacity needs in aviation, focusing on busy airports and airspace. The plan included technology solutions like RNAV procedures, WAAS for GPS accuracy, controller-pilot data link, and reduced vertical separation. NextGen, a $1 billion annual initiative, is a comprehensive plan to modernize air traffic control by replacing radar with GPS for precision navigation and aircraft tracking. It builds on earlier FAA initiatives like WAAS and controller-pilot data link technologies to increase operating flexibility and efficiency in routing aircraft. The NextGen program, funded by over $1 billion annually through the FAA's Facilities and Equipment account, includes core components such as Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast (ADS-B). This system broadcasts and receives aircraft data like identification, position, altitude, heading, and speed using GPS receivers. ADS-B Out transmits position data, while ADS-B In allows aircraft to receive signals from other aircraft and ground stations for traffic, weather, and flight information. FAA funds support the installation and maintenance of the ground network for ADS-B transmissions. Most aircraft will be required to have ADS-B Out functionality. The NextGen program includes core components like ADS-B Out capability for aircraft by 2020, SWIM for data sharing, DataComm for digital voice and data network, and CATMT for enhancing aircraft flow management. NextGen includes automation tools and decision support systems to improve aircraft flow management, leveraging technologies like SWIM. NVS upgrades voice communications infrastructure, NextGen Weather provides a common weather picture. FAA modernization initiatives are crucial for NextGen, with ERAM program seen as a key milestone. The FAA has implemented performance-based navigation procedures to improve airport access and operational efficiency for NextGen. Most air carrier fleets are equipped with PBN navigation equipment, allowing the use of NextGen procedures like RNAV. However, a small percentage of the general aviation fleet is equipped for NextGen, with stakeholder reluctance being a major challenge for FAA in implementation. The FAA faces stakeholder reluctance in adopting NextGen technologies due to uncertainties about technical details and benefits. In May 2010, FAA mandated aircraft operators to equip with approved ADS-B Out equipment by 2020, rejecting the no-action alternative to accommodate increasing air traffic. A cost-benefit analysis of the final rule for a uniform equipment mandate in air traffic control identified benefits of $6.8 billion to $8.5 billion over 2009-2035, including time and fuel savings, CO2 emissions reductions, and increased system capacity. Costs ranged from $3.3 billion to $7.0 billion, with avionics equipage costs estimated at $2.5 billion to $6.2 billion. FAA noted potential disproportionate impacts on small U.S. business operators. The FAA estimated that small operators would struggle to recover compliance costs, with over 1,500 facing costs exceeding 1% of annual revenues. Additionally, more than 1,000 operators would incur costs exceeding 2% of annual revenues. The total costs to general aviation were estimated to be between $1.2 billion to $4.5 billion. The FAA proposed a "best-equipped best-served" concept to incentivize early investment in NextGen technologies, offering benefits such as preferential treatment in flight routing. ADS-B technology could also provide benefits, especially to small general aviation aircraft, by providing pilots with traffic and weather data. The FAA plans to promote potential benefits of NextGen technologies, including robust traffic and weather data for small general aviation aircraft. There is no formal policy on best-equipped best-served practices, with implementation varying by region and airport. NextGen technologies are expected to improve efficiency and safety for both commercial and general aviation operators, reducing time, fuel burn, and environmental impacts. Commercial airlines will benefit from more direct routing and reduced flight delays under NextGen. The FAA has implemented a best-equipped best-served model for commercial operators using NextGen technologies, providing priority access to certain airports and flight routes. This results in fuel savings, improved customer satisfaction, reduced operational costs, and environmental benefits. General aviation operators will also benefit from improved airspace and airport access with NextGen-equipped aircraft. The FAA developed the Wide Area Augmentation System (WAAS) in 1995 to improve navigational accuracy for civil aviation. WAAS consists of ground stations that correct GPS signals and transmit them to satellites for broadcast to WAAS-enabled GPS devices on aircraft. This system allows for instrument approaches to airports using WAAS and GPS for lateral and vertical guidance, providing access to thousands of airports under various weather conditions. WAAS and GPS provide lateral and vertical guidance for aircraft, allowing access to additional airports in poor weather conditions. FAA has published over 3,000 approach procedures using this technology, with plans for over 5,000 by 2016. These procedures enable pilots to descend to 200 feet above ground in 1.5-mile visibility before establishing visual contact with the runway, reducing diversions and fuel costs. WAAS maintenance costs are significantly lower than traditional ILS systems, with no ground equipment to maintain. WAAS eliminates the need for ground equipment maintenance at airports. Costs mainly involve upkeep of runway lighting and markings for approach certification, and addressing impacts of new structures near the approach path. While not a core NextGen technology, WAAS enables precision airport approach procedures. ADS-B In functionality, along with WAAS-enabled navigation equipment, offers benefits to operators. FAA ground stations transmit TIS-B and FIS-B data for free to equipped aircraft. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 established a general aviation equipage fund to enhance safety by improving pilot situation awareness. NEXA Capital Partners anticipates making $550 million available in capital for general aviation equipage financing over the next 10 years through low-cost loans to qualified aircraft owners. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 established a general aviation equipage fund to improve safety by enhancing pilot awareness. NEXA Capital Partners plans to provide $550 million in low-cost loans over the next decade for aircraft owners to equip their planes with NextGen avionics, addressing concerns about safety improvements and funding challenges for NextGen infrastructure development. Total costs for NextGen infrastructure are estimated to be between $14 billion to $22 billion. The cost to upgrade the civilian aircraft fleet with NextGen avionics could range from $14 billion to $20 billion. Estimates suggest that equipping aircraft may cost less than $12 billion initially, with potential cost reductions as equipment is mass-produced. However, there are concerns that costs could increase significantly if schedules are delayed and decisions on technical specifications are not made promptly. The DOT OIG warns that some NextGen capabilities may not be fully implemented until 2035 or later, potentially exceeding the projected total cost estimate of $40 billion. Global harmonization of equipment and procedural standards, especially with European air traffic management initiatives, is also a policy concern. Consolidation of FAA air traffic facilities aims to control costs, replace outdated facilities, and improve services. Efforts have focused on TRACON facilities in major metropolitan areas, with recent projects expanding consolidation across larger geographical areas. The FAA is consolidating air traffic control functions across larger areas, replacing outdated combined tower/TRACON facilities with separate tower-only designs. TRACON components are being relocated to consolidated facilities, potentially leading to outsourcing of operations at low-activity towers under the FCT program. This consolidation plan has faced controversy due to ongoing evolution and concerns raised by FAA labor unions. The FAA is in the early stages of planning for consolidating air traffic control functions into large integrated facilities. This effort includes realignment and consolidation of services and facilities, which could result in job changes and modernization under the NextGen system. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 required the FAA to develop a report with recommendations for this consolidation. The FAA is planning to consolidate air traffic control functions into large integrated facilities, including realignment and consolidation of services and facilities.
